p.s: Both of the characters, Amir and Abe, are introduced to the audience in the first scene of the play Disgraced, Scene 4.
To analyse the connection and relationship of those two characters their single behaviour should be looked at first.
Amir is being presented as an American with south asianSouth Asian heritage.
He grew up in a conservative, islamicIslamic household and was fully commited to his religion in his childhood days.
The Amir that is portraiedportrayed in the play completely changed.
After coming to America, he changed his name, values and turned his back to the Islam and everything that has to do with it.
He changed his name from Abdullah to Hussein, and at work he pretends to be Hindu.
Moreover he married a white American woman and adapted fully to the American lifestyle, as he became a successful attornyattorney in the country.
Amir Hussein is a great example of Assimillationassimilation, as when he took over the American lifestyle and values, he left his roots and religion behind.
Abe on the other hand, integrated in the country.
He changed his name, but only did so because the Quran allows to do so.
He changed his exterior traits, as he wears American clothes and adapted his name, but didn't quite change his thoughts and values like Amir did.
In contrast to his uncle he doesn't deniedeny where he comes from, and still stands up for his religion and the values that come with it.
One can clearly see their different thoughts based on the case of Imam Fareed, an Islamic person who got arrested for being a possible terrorist, even though it is clear that he is not guilty.
Abe asks Amir to help him as he would rather have one of his people as his lawyer.
With his people he refers to the muslimsMuslims, which shows that they still believe Amir is one of them, even though he often states that he doesn't want to belong there.
The fact that he asks his uncle shows that he still feels like he is one of them and looks up to them.
In the first scene, he clearly has respect for him.
The turning point of the play is the third scene and at the end of the scene also highlights the turning point of the relationship between Amir and Abe.
After Amir broke down and became physically aggressive, his forcefullforceful assimilation and his adapted value faded.
The given 4th scene shows the final identities of the characters.
In contrast to the beginning of the play, Abe is now fully commited to the Islam and the islamic culture.
He changed his name back and it seems like the few American values he adapted, faded away completely.
In the scene he states, that he laughed, when the officers brought up his immigrant status and that fact that it's up fo renewal (cf. l. 1-3).
This makes the audience think, that he doesn't care anymore and thinks not only this situation, but the whole country is hilarious, as the police symbolizes the legal term of a country.

The Abe from the beginning, who looked up to his uncle who managed to adapt to the country completely faded and now it seems like he even looks down on him as he tries to convince him with his perspective and values (cf. 10).
Throughout the whole play, Emily was the white savior of Amir who tries to adapt him to America and it'sits society.
It seems ironic, that now Abe also seems like a saviour, but one that tries to overbring his islamicIslamic values.
It is a strong contrast that probably stands in conectionconnection to AmirsAmir's outburst, in which he outlived certain Islamic values, that according to him are written down in the Quran.
Another diffrencedifference in their relationship is the faddingfading trust, that Abe gives his uncle.
In the beginning he counted on Amir, anand his help, as he volunteered to come to him and ask for help.
In the fourth scene, Emily needed to bring Abe to Amir and forced him to talk about the situation.
The question So what?You don't believe that either? (l. 13), shows that Abe is deeply dissappointeddisappointed by his uncle and doesn't feel like he understands him anymore.
This can also be the case, as he is disappointed in the values Amir outlived.
Amir turned his back on every little piece connected with the Islam.
Every beautiful and positive thing.
How came in the end, he only acted upon everything negatively and aggressivaggressive?
Abe probably feels betrayed as Amir always said, that the Islam is a backway of thinking, but in the end fulfiledfulfilled all prejudices people have against the Islam.
Correspondingly one could also say, that as a result of AmirsAmir's acts and aggressivaggressive bheaviour, Abe commited to the Islam again.

He probably thinks that even Amir, who seems so perfectly adapted to American society, isn't able to help but fall back to the Islam, why should he try to integrate anymore and not just outlives his values as well.
It seems like in the end both of them lost their connection to America, because of racism on a daily base and their corresponding acts against it.

The differenceis that Amir is clearly ashamed of him for falling back to his past, while Abe thinks the other way around, as he is proud to be a fully commited muslim again and even denies his americanAmerican past (cf. l. 54-73).
Moreover there is a difference between how Amir handles the legal situation.
In the beginning of the play, he decided to go to the trial of Imam Fareed and acted upon AbesAbe's wish.
Even though Emily convinced him, he went there as a sign of support towards a muslim.
Now he doesn't even suggest helping Abe himself, as he's a lawyer too, but directly calls Ken, another lawyer to take over Abe's case (cf. l. 19).
This symbolizes the way they slowly became strangers.
A thing that didn't change, is that Amir thought of Abe as a kid in the beginning and still does so.
When you steppstep out your parents' house(cf. l. 21).
He portraisportrays Abe as a childish, naive person, who doesn't quite understand the consequences that can come with certain behaviour.
He indirectly shames him for not having fully adapted to American values and society even though ironically he hasn't himself.
But Amir obviously wants to change things, which is highlighted, when Abe asks him wheatherwhether he would work for the FBIFederal Bureau of Investigation, if he was asked to.
Again this seems like Abe thinks of Amir as a traitor, someone who denies his roots and origin.
He states that he's not on the side of the authorities side, even though Amir wants to (cf. 33-35).
This again underlines the naivitynaivety of AbesAbe's character, as he actually is from America and grew up with the legal forms of the country.
Here one again can see the contrast between Abe and Amir.
Abe denies his country and still wants to go back to Pakistan.
He can't believe that America could provide a better life for them (cf. l. 39-50).
That's probably because he always had to face the bad sides of society.
A society full of racism against people who come from there, but are treated like outcasts just because they look diffrentdifferent.
He differs himself from Amir by the fact, that he wansn'twasn't born here and doesn't feel like he belongs there.
He also wants to make Amir see, that the country only provides problems, as he talks about him loosinglosing his job and his aggressive outburst (l. 48-50).
In the end both of the fight about how Abe lost his respect for Amir.
He eventually reveals that Amir hurtedhurt him by turning his back on him and that from nowonnow on he will handle things himself (l. 74-75).
The fact that he still calls him uncle seems ironic here.
In conclusion one can say that the realtionshiprelationship between Abe and Amir changed drastically throughout the play.
Especially after the turning point in scene 3 and the following scene, one can analyse the obvious difference.
